greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = C(2n-1,n-1) mod n^3.
comment: For p prime > 3, Joseph Wolstenholme showed in 1862 that a(p)=1. - corrected by _Jonathan Sondow_, Jan 24 2016
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
maple: seq(binomial(2*n-1,n-1) mod n^3, n=1..100); # _Robert Israel_, Jan 24 2016
mathematica: Table[Mod[Binomial[2 n - 1, n - 1], n^3], {n, 1, 50}] (* _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jan 24 2016 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = binomial(2*n-1, n-1) % n^3; \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jan 24 2016
(MAGMA) [Binomial(2*n-1, n-1) mod n^3: n in [1..50]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jan 24 2016
results.author: _Henry Bottomley_, Oct 29 2004
